title: 103_s1663
content: The Act may be cited as the "Domestic Chemical Diversion Control Act of 1993" and includes definition amendments. The Controlled Substances Act of 1993 is amended to redefine certain chemicals as list I or list II chemicals, specifying their importance in manufacturing. The Controlled Substances Act of 1993 is amended to redefine certain chemicals as list I or list II chemicals, specifying their importance in manufacturing. Amendments include changes to paragraphs related to international transactions involving listed chemicals, tableting machines, and encapsulating machines. The Controlled Substances Act of 1993 is amended to redefine certain chemicals as list I or list II chemicals, specifying their importance in manufacturing. Amendments include changes to paragraphs related to international transactions involving listed chemicals, tableting machines, and encapsulating machines. Any transaction in a listed chemical contained in a drug that may be marketed lawfully in the US under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is subject to certain conditions. The Controlled Substances Act of 1993 is amended to redefine certain chemicals as list I or list II chemicals, specifying their importance in manufacturing. Amendments include changes to paragraphs related to international transactions involving listed chemicals, tableting machines, and encapsulating machines. Any transaction in a listed chemical contained in a drug that may be marketed lawfully in the US under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is subject to certain conditions, including the diversion of drugs to obtain listed chemicals for illicit production of controlled substances. The Controlled Substances Act of 1993 is amended to redefine certain chemicals as list I or list II chemicals, specifying their importance in manufacturing. Amendments include changes to paragraphs related to international transactions involving listed chemicals, tableting machines, and encapsulating machines. The term 'international transaction' is defined as a transaction involving the shipment of a listed chemical across an international border in which a broker or trader located in the United States participates. The terms 'broker' and 'trader' refer to persons assisting in arranging international transactions in listed chemicals by negotiating contracts or serving as intermediaries. The Controlled Substances Act of 1993 is amended to redefine certain chemicals as list I or list II chemicals, specifying their importance in manufacturing. Amendments include changes to paragraphs related to international transactions involving listed chemicals, tableting machines, and encapsulating machines. The term 'international transaction' is defined as a transaction involving the shipment of a listed chemical across an international border in which a broker or trader located in the United States participates. The terms 'broker' and 'trader' refer to persons assisting in arranging international transactions in listed chemicals by negotiating contracts or serving as intermediaries. The amendment removes the exemption of certain drugs. The amendment removes the exemption of certain drugs. The Attorney General will remove drugs from exemption if they are being diverted for illicit production of controlled substances. Factors considered include scope of diversion, ease of use in production, and recoverability of listed chemicals. The Attorney General will limit the designation of drugs removed from exemption to the most identifiable type unless evidence suggests otherwise. Manufacturers can apply for reinstatement of exemption if they can prove their drug products are not being diverted. The Attorney General considers various factors when deciding to reinstate the exemption for a drug product, including packaging, distribution, evidence of diversion, manufacturer actions to prevent diversion, and other relevant factors for public health and safety. A transaction involving a drug product pending application for reinstatement of exemption filed with the Attorney General within 60 days of a regulation removing the exemption is not considered a regulated transaction during the application process. The Attorney General can deny the application if there is evidence of drug diversion. The Attorney General can deny an application for reinstatement of exemption for a drug product if there is evidence of drug diversion. Regulations reinstating an exemption can be modified or revoked if the drug product is being diverted or if there is a significant change in the data that led to the issuance of the regulation. Section 204 removes exemptions for certain drugs, amending the Controlled Substances Act to regulate listed chemicals. Registration requirements are outlined in Section 3. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to include regulations for listed chemicals and registration requirements for regulated persons and transactions. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to include regulations for listed chemicals and registration requirements for regulated persons and transactions. Section 303 is amended to require registration for distribution of list I chemicals, with considerations for diversion controls and compliance with federal regulations. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to include regulations for listed chemicals and registration requirements for regulated persons and transactions. Section 304 is amended to consider factors such as compliance with laws, prior convictions, experience in chemical distribution, and public health and safety when denying, revoking, or suspending registration for list I chemicals. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to include regulations for listed chemicals and registration requirements for regulated persons and transactions. Section 304 is amended to consider factors such as compliance with laws, prior convictions, experience in chemical distribution, and public health and safety when denying, revoking, or suspending registration for list I chemicals. Amendments include inserting "or list I chemical" after "controlled substance" in various subsections. In amending the Controlled Substances Act, registration requirements for importing or exporting list I chemicals are addressed. The Attorney General must register applicants unless there are determinations against it. The Attorney General must register applicants for importing or exporting list I chemicals unless it is against the public interest. Factors considered include those specified in section 303(h). Amendments also include the addition of list I chemicals in certain paragraphs. Amendments to the Controlled Substances Act include adding list I chemicals to prohibited acts, such as possessing equipment or materials for manufacturing controlled substances and distributing related equipment. Amendments to the Controlled Substances Act now prohibit possessing equipment or materials for manufacturing controlled substances and distributing related equipment, including list I chemicals. Amendments to the Controlled Substances Act now prohibit possessing equipment or materials for manufacturing controlled substances and distributing related equipment, including list I chemicals. Additionally, an anti-smuggling provision is added to the Controlled Substances Import and Export Act, which prohibits the import or export of listed chemicals in violation of specific sections. Administrative inspections and authority are also addressed in the amendments. Amendments to the Controlled Substances Act now include regulations on places where controlled substances can be held, manufactured, and distributed, as well as the maintenance of related records. Additionally, amendments address the distribution of equipment and materials for manufacturing controlled substances and the import/export of listed chemicals. Amendments to the Controlled Substances Act now include regulations on places where controlled substances can be held, manufactured, and distributed, as well as the maintenance of related records. Additionally, amendments address the distribution of equipment and materials for manufacturing controlled substances and the import/export of listed chemicals. The amendment involves adding "or chemical" after "such substance" and "controlled substance" to the Act. SEC. 6. FORFEITURE EXPANSION. Amends the Controlled Substances Act to include forfeiture of listed chemicals. SEC. 7. THRESHOLD AMOUNTS. Amends the Act to establish threshold amounts for listed chemicals. SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act and its amendments will take effect 120 days after enactment.
